questions.text: Which mental functions are examined in the Mental State Examination (100-7)?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Concentration

General description:
  • Appearance and behaviour
  • Motor activity Speech

Emotional state:
  • Mood: subjective experience of patient’s internal and sustained emotional state
  • Affect: expression of mood (that appears to the clinician)

Thinking:
  • Thought content
  • Thought process
  • Perceptual disturbances

Cognition (higher mental function): most commonly evaluated by Mini-Mental Status Examination (MMSE)
  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention & calculation
  • Memory (immediate, recent & long term)
  • Abstract reasoning
  • Insight & Judgement

questions.text: A teacher demonstrates the proper handwashing technique to her students, who then practice it both at school and at home. What type of learning does this scenario represent?
questions.explanation:
Domains of learning

Psychomotor
  • Psychomotor learning involves acquiring physical skills and coordination through observation, practice and repetition, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain.
  • It is measured based on speed, precision, distance and procedure in execution
  • It includes imitation, manipulation, precision, articulation and naturalisation
  • E.g., An intern learning how to insert an IV cannula by observing the staff nurse

Affective learning

(Option C)
  • Includes domain of attitude and values
  • It includes emotions, feelings, attitudes, and values
  • It encompasses the subjective experiences and expressions of emotions.
  • E.g., communicating with patients with empathy

Cognitive learning

(Option A)
  • It refers to mental processes related to knowledge acquisition, understanding, thinking, and problem-solving.
  • It involves perception, memory, attention, language, and reasoning processes.
  • E.g., Solving NEET PG entrance exam MCQs

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.explanation:
Abnormal thought process

Derailment
  • Sudden or gradual deviation in thought (without blocking) is often used synonymously with loosening associations.

Talking Past the Point (Vorbeireden)
  • The patient responds with incorrect answers related to the topic despite understanding the question.
  • Example: Saying "white" for grass colour and "green" for snow colour.
  • Seen in hysterical pseudodementia (dissociative disorder) and Ganser’s syndrome (approximate answers).
  • It also occurs in acute schizophrenia, especially in adolescents (hebephrenia).

Loosening of Associations
  • Disorganised thought progression, shifting between unrelated topics, leading to incoherent communication.

Incoherence
  • Disconnected, disorganised, or incomprehensible speech.
  • Word Salad: Incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.

Word Approximation


 
  • Using conventional words in an unconventional way (e.g., "hand shoes" for gloves)
  • It is distinguished from a neologism, a newly created word with an unclear or unknown origin.

questions.text: In the physiology viva, the examiner inquires about the individual who initially recorded the first EEG. You respond by admitting that you are unaware of the answer. Sympathetic to your lack of knowledge, the examiner provides a hint indicating that the name resembles a common item found at McDonald's. With this clue, you are able to recall the name and provide the correct response. Which form of memory is involved in this situation?
Which one of the options below is not classified as a form of subcortical dementia?

  • ↳ Presence of one or more bizarre or non-bizarre delusional thoughts for at least one month or longer. In bizarre delusion, patients have scientifically impossible and un-understandable thoughts. In non-bizarre delusion, patients may have false but not impossible thoughts. The individual's cultural beliefs should also be considered when assessing the delusions.

Form of Thought

Content of Thought

Possession of Thought

It involves the speed and continuity of thinking.

It refers to the organization or association between thoughts.

It refers to the ideas, beliefs, and concepts that a person thinks about.

It involves the feeling that thoughts are controlled by oneself or some external force.

Abnormalities may include Flight of ideas, inhibition, or slow thinking.

It includes disorders like derailment, loosening of association, incoherence, tangentiality, neologism, circumstantiality, metonyms, clanging, and thought block.

It includes different types of delusions, such as delusions of persecution (most common in schizophrenia), delusions of reference, grandiosity, infidelity, enormity, love, guilt, etc.

It includes the disorders like thought allientation and obsessions.

questions.text: What would be the score on the insight scale for a patient who attributes their mental distress to the summer season?
questions.explanation:
Score

Description

0

No insight

1

Awareness of having a mental illness

2

Slight awareness of illness

3

Insight present but overvalued ideation

4

Insight present but not consistent

5

Good insight
